label: Forearm length
represented_in: Castillo-Figueroa_2021, Soria_2021, Cosentino_2023, Froidevaux_2023, Gonçalvez_2018, Stevens_2018, Pereira_2018, Presley_2018, Reardon_2017, Scheiner_2017, Briones-Salas_2017, Wordley_2017, García-Morales_2016, Cisneros_2014, Stevens_2014, Stevens_2013, Hanspach_2012, Lucho_2017, Carrasco-Rueda_2020, Pereira_2019
description:
Measurement from the base of the elbow (tip of the olecranon process) to 
the distal region of the forearm where it joins the carpus

label: Sexual dimorphism in size
description: Presence of sexual dimorphism in size

label: Length of the third digit
description:
In biological collections the trait is the result of the sum of the 
metacarpus and its three phalanges. The metacarpus is measured from the 
joint with the phalanx to the junction with the carpus. The phalanx is 
measured as the maximum distance between the joints. In the field, the 
trait is measured from the junction of the metacarpus with the carpus to 
the tip of the third phalanx

label: Length of the fifth digit
description:
In biological collections the trait is the result of the sum of the 
metacarpus and its two phalanges. The metacarpus is measured from the joint 
with the phalanx to the junction with the carpus. The phalanx is measured 
as the maximum distance between the joints. In the field, it is measured 
from the junction of the metacarpus with the carps to the tip of the second 
phalanx

label: Wing loading
represented_in: Castillo-Figueroa_2021, Cosentino_2023, Froidevaux_2023, Crane_2022, Monadjem_2018, Pereira_2018, Presley_2018, Scheiner_2017, García-Morales_2016, Cisneros_2014, Hanspach_2012, Fukui_2009, Carrasco-Rueda_2020, Pereira_2019
description:
Wing loading (Wl) is body mass in kg times acceleration of gravity (Mg) 
divided by its wing area in m2 (S); *gravity acceleration = 9.8 m/s2; Wl = 
Mg/S (N/m2)

label: total_wing_loading
description: Body weight divided by lifting_surface_area

label: relative_partial_loading
description: partial_wing_loading divided by body mass raised to the 1/3 power. Body mass, not weight should be used

label: relative_total_loading
description: total_wing_loading divided by body mass raised to 1/3. Body mass, not weight should be used

label: Aspect ratio
represented_in: Castillo-Figueroa_2021, Cosentino_2023, Froidevaux_2023, Crane_2022, Laurindo_2020, Farneda_2018, Monadjem_2018, Pereira_2018, Presley_2018, Scheiner_2017, Wordley_2017, García-Morales_2016, Farneda_2015, Cisneros_2014, Hanspach_2012, Fukui_2009, Carrasco-Rueda_2020, Pereira_2019, Coelho_2018
description:
Aspect ratio (A) is the result of the wing span squared (m2) (B) divided by 
wing area (m2) (S); A = B2/S

label: total_aspect_ratio
description: The wingspan squared, divided by lifting_surface_area

label: Tip shape index
description:
Tip shape index (I) is the tip area ratio (Ts) divided by tip length ratio 
(Tl) minus Ts; I = Ts/(Tl-Ts)

label: Wing span
description:
Measurement taken from tip to tip of the extended wings held along to the 
long axis of the body

label: Wing length (F/M/U)
description: Length of the wing

label: Wing area (F/M/U)
description: Area of the two wings

label: lifting_surface_area
description: The total area of the patagium, uropatagium (if present), and body excluding the head

label: wing_area_rec
description: The rectangular approximation of the patagium based on the wing length (measured from the edge of the body to the wing tip) multiplied by the wing width (measured from the end of the fifth digit to the tip of the fifth digit)

label: Length of the pollex with claw

label: Reproductive status
allowed_values_levels:
For females the frequencies or population averages of each stage: 
Proestrus. Estrus. Metestrus. Anestrus. For males the frequencies or 
population averages of: Scrotted males Non-scrotted males
description:
Reproductive stage that involves hormonal concentration (progesterone and 
estradiol peaks) and physiological changes in females (corpus luteum and 
ovarian follicle). Vaginal smears can reveal superficial nucleated cells 
(proestrus), superficial non-nucleated cells parabasal (estrus), 
intermediate cells (metestrus) and parabasal cells (anestrus) in bat 
females. Females can be considered reproductive when they presented a 
dominance in proestrus, estrus, and metestrus. By contrast, 
non-reproductive females are when the dominant stage is anestrus. This can 
be measured individually and can also be expressed in frequencies or 
population averages of each stage. For males, reproductive status can be 
determined by examining testes (scrotted or not), thus obtaining 
frequencies or population averages of each condition.

description: Sex of the specimens

description: Time between reproduction events in days

Bat capacity to obtain nutrients when consumption item differ in nutrient

description: Skewness index of the seasonal activity pattern: if values <-0.5: indication of a substantially skewed distribution towards the spring, if values >0.5: indication of a substantially skewed distribution towards the autumn, if values [-0.5,5]: distribution fairly symmetrical with peak around mid-summer

label: Bite force
description:
Is the result of the interplay between the teeth, the masticatory muscles, 
the mandible, the maxillae, and temporomandibular joints. Bite force can be 
measured *in vivo* with an isometric Kistler force transducer or can be 
estimated with assessments of muscular and bony morphology from skulls 
using algorithms

label: mobility
description: Based on the relationship between mean and maximum recapture distances (Fig. S3), using both recapture data obtained during our study and from the radio-tracking and mark-recapture literature (see Table S1 for a complete list of references). Species were grouped into three categories of mobility: low, intermediate, and high (see Fig. S3).

label: upper_elevation_m
description: Upper elevation limit at which the species can be found in meters

label: lower_elevation_m
description: Lower elevation limit at which the species can be found in meters

label: AltitudinalMigration
description: Altitudinal migration: yes, no, possible

label: altitude_breadth_m
description: Difference between the upper and lower elevation limits of a species in meters

label: island_dwelling
description: 20% or more of the breeding range occurs on an island

label: island_endemicity
allowed_values_levels: Exclusively marine, Occurs on mainland, Occurs on large land bridge islands: the species occurs on islands greater than 1,000 km2 that are separated from the mainland by water no more than 110 m deep. The islands would have been part of the mainland during the last glacial maximum., Occurs on small land bridge islands: the species occurs on islands smaller than 1,000 km2 that are separated from the mainland by water no more than 110 m deep. The islands would have been part of the mainland during the last glacial maximum., Occurs only on isolated islands: the species occurs on islands separated from the mainland by water deeper than 110 m.
description: Score of island endemicity obtained from species’ ranges and historical and fossil occurrence records

label: Geopolitical.endemism
description: Using the same criteria (IUCN Red List assessments), we categorised species endemism as geopolitically endemic (e.g., country-endemic, and non-endemic) when a species occurs only in a single country or state territory, and island endemism was classified as island-restricted or predominantly mainland.

label: dissected_by_mountains
description: Range dissected by mountains (based on elevation gradients with slopes equal or higher than 5 degrees)

label: glaciation
description: Historical exposure to glaciation, considered as more than 20% range overlap with areas glaciated in the last 21000 years Binary

label: biogeographical_realm
allowed_values_levels: Afrotropical, Antarctic, Australasian, Indomalayan, Nearctic, Neotropical, Oceanian, Palearctic
description: Biogeographical realms in which the species can be encountered

label: EstExtentOccurrence
description: Estimated extent of occurrence: area contained within the shortest continuous imaginary boundary which can be drawn to encompass all the known, inferred or projected sites of present occurrence of a taxon, excluding cases of vagrancy

label: GeographicRange
description: Spatial area where a species is found

label: Natural.range
description: For all species, we estimated their present natural ranges (Peterken 1977), which is potential current natural ranges if species had never experienced strong anthropogenic pressures.

label: habitat_breadth_n
description: Number of distinct suitable level 1 IUCN habitats

label: Habitat
allowed_values_levels: Forest, Wetlands, Artificial Landscape, Caves and Subterranean Areas, Rocky Areas, Savanna, Desert, Shrubland, Grassland, Captivity
description: The terrestrial habitat types used by this database are listed below and are the standard terms used in the IUCN Red List Habitats Authority File (Version 3.0). For more information please see IUCN Habitats Classification Scheme.

label: SpeciesHabitatSpecializationIndex
description: Species habitat specialisation index: degree of specialisation of a species in its use of a habitat for foraging/commuting calculated using the coefficient of variation: higher values indicate high level of specialisation towards a given habitat.

label: DeciduousForestAffinitySmallScale
description: Estimated response to decideous forest at 50 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: ConiferousForestAffinitySmallScale
description: Estimated response to coniferous forest at 50 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: DenseUrbanAreaAffinitySmallScale
description: Estimated response to dense urban area at 50 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: FreshwaterAffinitySmallScale
description: Estimated response to freshwater at 50 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: CroplandAffinitySmallScale
description: Estimated response to cropland at 50 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: GrasslandAffinitySmallScale
description: Estimated response to grassland at 50 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: DeciduousForestAffinityMediumScale
description: Estimated response to decideous forest at 500 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: ConiferousForestAffinityMediumScale
description: Estimated response to coniferous at 500 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: DenseUrbanAreaAffinityMediumScale
description: Estimated response to dense urban area at 500 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: FreshwaterAffinityMediumScale
description: Estimated response to freshwater at 500 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: CroplandAffinityMediumScale
description: Estimated response to cropland at 500 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: GrasslandAffinityMediumScale
description: Estimated response to grassland at 500 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: DeciduousForestAffinityLargeScale
description: Estimated response to cropland at 5000 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: ConiferousForestAffinityLargeScale
description: Estimated response to grassland at 5000 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: GrasslandAffinityLargeScale
description: Estimated response to grassland at 5000 m radius buffer scale calculated from generalized linear mixed model

label: Forest
description: We described species’ major habitat breadth based on IUCN Level 1 classification https://www.iucnredlist.org/resources/habitat-classification-scheme (Caves, Forests, Savanna, Desert, Urban, Artificial, and Wetlands).

label: Savanna
description: We described species’ major habitat breadth based on IUCN Level 1 classification https://www.iucnredlist.org/resources/habitat-classification-scheme (Caves, Forests, Savanna, Desert, Urban, Artificial, and Wetlands).

description: We described species’ major habitat breadth based on IUCN Level 1 classification https://www.iucnredlist.org/resources/habitat-classification-scheme (Caves, Forests, Savanna, Desert, Urban, Artificial, and Wetlands).

label: Type of roost
allowed_values_levels:
Animal burrow or hole; Termite ant/nest; Cavity in fallen tree; Cavity in 
standing tree; Exposed on standing tree; Foliage, leaf tent; Foliage, 
unmodified foliage; Rocks, crevices, or caves; Under fallen tree; Undercut 
earth bank
description: Diurnal roosts used by bats

description: Roost type of the species

label: Roost type/Crevices in trees (CRT)
description: Roost type of the species

label: Roost type/Caves and sinkhole (CA)
description: Roost type of the species

description: Roost type of the species

description: Roost type of the species

label: Roost type/Rocky outcrops (RO)
description: Roost type of the species

label: Roost type/Holes in the ground (HG)
description: Roost type of the species

label: OvergroundRoostDependence-Castle
allowed_values_levels: 0: no dependence, 1: low dependence, 2: moderate dependence, 3: high dependence, 4: very high dependence, 5: extremely high dependence.
description: Degree of dependence on castle/fortification as overground roost: 0: no dependence, 1: low dependence, 2: moderate dependence, 3: high dependence, 4: very high dependence, 5: extremely high dependence.

allowed_values_levels: 0: no dependence, 1: low dependence, 2: moderate dependence, 3: high dependence, 4: very high dependence, 5: extremely high dependence.

allowed_values_levels: 0: no dependence, 1: low dependence, 2: moderate dependence, 3: high dependence, 4: very high dependence, 5: extremely high dependence.

allowed_values_levels: 0: no dependence, 1: low dependence, 2: moderate dependence, 3: high dependence, 4: very high dependence, 5: extremely high dependence.

label: Nursery roost
description: Presence of nursery roost

label: Nursery roost size
description: Number of individuals in a nursery roost

label: FirstMainHibernationRoost
allowed_values_levels: Thermally stable underground roosts (e.g. caves, mines, etc.), thermally unstable underground roosts (e.g. cellar, bunker, etc.), human-made roost (e.g. buildings, barns, churches, etc.), tree roost (e.g. holes, crevices, barck pockets, etc.), rock crevices

allowed_values_levels: Thermally stable underground roosts (e.g. caves, mines, etc.), thermally unstable underground roosts (e.g. cellar, bunker, etc.), human-made roost (e.g. buildings, barns, churches, etc.), tree roost (e.g. holes, crevices, barck pockets, etc.), rock crevices

label: Colony size
description: Size of the colony

label: Mixed colony
description: Presence of different species in the same colony

label: Echolocation
description: Presence of echolocation

label: Echolocation type
allowed_values_levels: 1= CF (constant frequency), 2= FM (frequency modulated), 3= QCF (quasi- constant frequency)
description: The type of the echolocation call

label: echolocation frequency
allowed_values_levels: low = below 38 kHz, medium = 38–48 kHz, high = above 48 kHz, linear = vertically linear calls
description: Definition not specified in database; Check in article for more details

label: CallBandwidth
description: The range of frequencies through which an echolocation call sweeps

label: Duration
description: Time span of the call emitted by the bat

label: Interval
description: Time between one call to another emitted by the bat

label: Frequency
description:
Number of pressure waves of the call emitted by the bat that pass by a 
reference point per unit time. This can include the start of the call 
(initial frequency), the end of the call (final frequency) and the maximum 
amplitude of the call (maximum frequency)

label: End frequency (EF)
description: End frequency of the call

label: CallMaxFrequency
description: Maximum frequency value of the call

label: CallMidFrequency
description: Frequency of highest energy taken at half call duration

label: CallMinFrequency
description: Minimum frequency value of the call

label: CallSlope
description: Total slope of the call, calculated from the difference in frequency and time from the point of highest frequency to the point of the characteristic frequency

label: CallStartFrequency
description: Frequency value measured at the beginning of the call

label: rateBuzz
description: Number of feeding buzzes per hour

label: buzzDuration
description: Duration of a feeding buzz (including pre-buzz phase)

label: buzzPeakFrequency
description: Frequency with the greatest amount of energy in a feeding buzz call

label: Intensity
description: Height of the sound pressure wave emitted by the bat

label: Harmonics
description: Wave that is a multiple of the fundamental frequency emitted by the bat

label: AllelicRichness
description: Average number of alleles (genetic variants) per microsatellite locus

label: CompleteMitochondrialGenome(bp)
description: Number of base pairs in complete mtDNA genome

label: GeneticPopulationStructure
description: Number of genetic sub-population clusters measured according to individual ancestry based on microsatellite or SNP datasets

label: GenomeSize_(Gb)
description: The amount of DNA in the genome measured as number of nucleotide base pairs

label: Hybridization
description: Hybridization: yes, no, possible

label: Karyotype
description: Number of chromosomes

label: Linage
description: Number of genetic lineages in the phylogenetic tree constructed with nuclear DNA or mitochondrial DNA sequences

label: NF
description: Number of chromosomal arms

label: NFa
description: Number of autosomal arms

label: Type
allowed_values_levels: Visitation, Seed Dispersal, Pollination, Consumption, Roost, Host, Predation, Cohabitation, Transport
description: This database only contains accounts of bats interacting with other organisms and not hypotheses that they might (e.g. a flower has chiropterophilious features). We report what is published and do not assume that every visit to a flower results in pollination or that every fruit eaten results in seed dispersal. We do assume that every object that is consumed is destroyed in the process.

label: Pest control
description: Presence of pest control ecosystem service

label: Seed dispersal
description: Presence of seed dispersal ecosystem service

label: Pollination
description: Presence of pollination ecosystem service

label: Conservation status
allowed_values_levels: DD= Data Deficient, LC= Least Concern, NT= Near Threatened, VU= Vulnerable, EN= Endangered, CR= Critically Endangered, NE= Not Evaluated
description: Conservation status of the species

label: Population.status
description: Species current conservation status (Data Deficient, Least Concern, Near Threatened, Vulnerable, Endangered, and Critically Endangered) and population trends (e.g., Unknown, Decreasing, Stable, Increasing) were categorised using standard IUCN Red List assessments.

label: Threats/Overharvesting for food (OH)
description: Threats for the species

label: Threats/Deforestation (DE)
description: Threats for the species

label: Threats/Persecution (P)
description: Threats for the species

label: Vandalism
description: Direct threats (Tdir) refer to the threats or risks that are direct to or in cave systems with immediate and perceivable impacts on populations or behaviour of species. This category includes direct human impacts (e.g., persecution, eviction, and cave closures) and the use of caves for harvesting bats, tourism, religious visits, and mining (minerals or guano).

label: Threats/Habitat loss (HL)
description: Threats for the species

label: Urbanisation
description: Indirect threats (Tind) refer to the threats outside cave systems or within cave proximity, of which the impacts to populations are secondary or non-immediate but otherwise detrimental. Examples include deforestation, agriculture, and urbanisation.

label: Agricultural.conversion
description: Indirect threats (Tind) refer to the threats outside cave systems or within cave proximity, of which the impacts to populations are secondary or non-immediate but otherwise detrimental. Examples include deforestation, agriculture, and urbanisation.

label: Threats/Dead trees removal (DTR)
description: Threats for the species

label: Threats/Roost disturbance (RD)
description: Threats for the species

label: Invasive.species
description: Lastly, Natural threats (Tnat) refer to threats that are natural in origin, though their frequency may be impacted by human activities, and that may directly or indirectly impact populations, such as diseases (e.g., White-nose syndrome) and climate-driven risks (e.g., drought, extreme cold)
